titleStmt.title: Von Bertrand Russell an Ludwig Wittgenstein, 21. 6. 1919
titleStmt.author: Russell, Bertrand

sourceDesc.p: Original im BA. Publiziert (Cambridge Letters, S. 118f.; WiC, S. 94).

list.item: 2007/06: Conversion from Folio Flat File to XML

div.p: Your letter reached me today, but your MS. has not come yet. It is true that what you dictated to Moore was not intelligible to me, & he could give me no help. I think probably it is true that I shan't understand your MS till I see you, but it will be easier to get understanding from your talk if I have read the MS carefully first. At the moment, I could not get a passport to go abroad, but that won't last. I think probably it will be possible for us to meet at Christmas time, but it is not likely to be possible sooner.

I wrote only two post-cards, as I thought letters would not be allowed. But I wrote innumerable letters about you, trying to get greater freedom for you. They bore some slight fruit, but not as much as I hoped. I also wrote to your mother, but the letter was returned to me. ‒ Please don't be discouraged about my understanding your work. Throughout the war I did not think about philosophy, until, last summer, I found myself in prison, & beguiled my leisure by writing a popular text-book, which was all I could do under the circumstances. Now I am back at philosophy, & more in the mood to understand.

I shall read your MS the moment I get it, & return it. What will be the address to which it is to be returned? All friendship & affection from me to you. Don't be discouraged ‒ you will be understood in the end. Yours ever
